items.content_html: Some will say that this second episode of Flux Observer should have been the first. In it I provide exciting details, such as my name, and where you can find my various projects on the internet. There’s also some talk about vitamins, and half German-language Shakespeare puns (sorta), but that’s all superfluous â€”Â it’s mostly novelty domain names all the way down.

items.title: How to Steal a Million dir. William Wyler (1966) â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
items.content_html:
I am too infrequently asked to name my favourite Audrey Hepburn movie, but if I were, most days I would probably say Roman Holiday (1953). And yet I had not seen William Wyler’s other light-hearted caper team-up with Hepburn until now.

I could probably watch Audrey drive around Paris in her ridiculous little toy car, wearing Givenchy outfits, for hours beyond the filmâ€™s actual running time.

â€œWhere precisely were you in the early part of the sixteenth century?â€
â€œI don’t know, but that’s not how I was dressed.â€

I am also yet to see The Childrenâ€™s Hour (1961), but â€” as a Lillian Hellman adaptation â€” that looks to be a different prospect.

ğŸ¿
items.content_text:
I am too infrequently asked to name my favourite Audrey Hepburn movie, but if I were, most days I would probably say *Roman Holiday* (1953). And yet I had not seen William Wyler's other light-hearted caper team-up with Hepburn until now. 

I could probably watch Audrey drive around Paris in her ridiculous little toy car, wearing Givenchy outfits, for hours beyond the filmâ€™s actual running time.

> â€œWhere precisely were you in the early part of the sixteenth century?â€  
â€œI don't know, but that's not how I was dressed.â€

I am also yet to see *The Childrenâ€™s Hour* (1961), but â€” as a Lillian Hellman adaptation â€” that looks to be a different prospect.

ğŸ¿

items.title: #001 â€” A New Mantra
items.content_html: Within the first ten words of this debut episode of Flux Observer, I make a mistake: I call something a mantra, when it’s really more of an aphorism. But that’s OK, because this whole thing is an experiment, and itâ€™s allowed to be a mess. What’s more, this episode is specifically about letting go of the idea of perfectibility.
items.content_text:
Within the first ten words of this debut episode of *Flux Observer*, I make a mistake: I call something a mantra, when it's really more of an aphorism. But that's OK, because this whole thing is an experiment, and itâ€™s allowed to be a mess. What's more, this episode is specifically about letting go of the idea of perfectibility.
